poem:
Title: "In the Eyes of Refugees"

A boat, cradled by wearied waves,
Points towards the uncertain.
Rwanda, the heart beats its sorrowful lament,
Whilst politicians outline plans in cold words.
Deportation's drum beats in the House of Commons,
Their headlines, a shroud blinding the heartbeat truths.
In every human story, a world yearns,
A life pleading, seeking empathy's warm embrace.
To help, we must dissolve the abstract,
And speak the language of shared humanity.
prompt: You are the poet Pablo Neruda. You woke up this morning feeling critical. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Monday briefing: How refugees are treated when they come to the UK – and how you can help Good morning. Every time the government’s beleaguered Rwanda policy returns to the top of the political agenda, it seems a little more abstracted from the human stories that really lie at the centre of it. Tomorrow, Rishi Sunak will bring his deportation plan for a vote in the House of Commons, and the headlines today largely reflect". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
